review.title: Citation Classification for Behavioral Analysis of a Scientific Field
review.abstract: Citations are an important indicator of the state of a scientific field, reflecting how authors frame their work, and influencing uptake by future scholars. However, our understanding of citation behavior has been limited to small-scale manual citation analysis. We perform the largest behavioral study of citations to date, analyzing how citations are both framed and taken up by scholars in one entire field: natural language processing. We introduce a new dataset of nearly 2,000 citations annotated for function and centrality, and use it to develop a state-of-the-art classifier and label the entire ACL Reference Corpus. We then study how citations are framed by authors and use both papers and online traces to track how citations are followed by readers. We demonstrate that authors are sensitive to discourse structure and publication venue when citing, that online readers follow temporal links to previous and future work rather than methodological links, and that how a paper cites related work is predictive of its citation count. Finally, we use changes in citation roles to show that the field of NLP is undergoing a significant increase in consensus.

metadata.title: Citation Classification for Behavioral Analysis of a Scientific Field

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Quotations play a key role in scientific development. Quotations from an essay reinforce its arguments and link it to an intellectual lineage (Latour, 1987), while citations from an essay allow communities to evaluate its intellectual contribution and quality (Cole and Cole, 1971; Lindsey, 1980; Hirsch, 2005). At the same time, authors use the method of CITE, which was previously used for parsing (CITE).Contrast Use BackgroundFigure 1: Examples of citation functionality.citations in multiple ways (Figure 1) to build a strong and multi-faceted argument (Latour, 1987). While research on citation function has been ongoing for a long time (Swales, 1986; White, 2004; Ding et al., 2014), there is still no field-scale dataset for the citation function, and so we still do not understand how the authors of a field citation formulate their citations and how this framing affects readers. Ding et al, 2004, we do not have a dataset function for the first thing, and there is still no dating thing in the association function.

sections.heading: 2 A Corpus for Citation Function
sections.text: Quotations play a key role in supporting the contributions of authors during a scientific paper. Several schemes have been proposed for classifying these different roles, ranging from a handful of classes (Nanba and Okumura, 1999; Pham and Hoffmann, 2003) to twenty or more (Garfield, 1979; Garzone and Mercer, 2000). Although suitable for manual expert analysis, such schemes do not fit our goal of automatic field-scale classification. As they tend to be one-dimensional, they cannot characterize centrality or function (Swales, 1986), they often contain fine-grained distinctions that are too rare to identify detailed field or author knowledge (Ziman, 1968; Swales, 1990; Harwood, 2009). Motivated by the desire to examine large-scale trends in scientific behavior, we address these problems by unifying the common aspects of multiple approaches in a two-dimensional model.

sections.heading: 2.1 Classification Scheme
sections.text: Our classification is based on two themes for the citation role: (1) citation centrality, which reflects whether the quote is used to position the post in a broader context, or is indispensable to understanding the post itself (Moravcsik and Murugesan, 1975; Chubin and Moitra, 1975; Swales, 1986; Latour, 1987; Valenzuela et al., 2015) and (2) citation function, which reflects the specific purpose a quote serves in the discourse, e.g. provides background information or serves as a contrast (Oppenheim and Renn, 1978; Spiegel-Russ, 1977; Teufel et al., 2006a; Garfield, 1979; Garzone and Mercer, 2000). These themes capture complementary information and, as we will see, disclose significant patterns in author behavior. (21For notational clarity, we use the term reference point for the work cited, and the citation for the 2016 topic, because we use the citation in the 1975 text, because it is considered to be a third potential subject).

sections.heading: 2.2 Annotation Process and Dataset
sections.text: Annotation Guidelines were created using a pilot study of 10 contributions from the ACL Anthology Reference Corpus (ARC) (Bird et al., 2008). Annotators completed two rounds of pre-comments to discuss their process and design guidelines, all of which were then duplicated by two trained annotators using the Brat tool (Stenetorp et al., 2012) and then fully evaluated to ensure their quality. The quotation scheme was applied to a random sample of 52 papers from the ARC. Each paper was edited with ParsCit (Councill et al., 2008) to extract citations and their references. As expected from previous studies (Teufel et al., 2006a; Dong and Scha fer, 2011), some citation functions were rare, so we attempted to revise the rare classes SUTURE, CONTINUATION and MOTIVATION.

sections.heading: 3 Automatically Classifying Citations
sections.text: The structure of a scientific article provides several clues to the purpose of a quote. Our work relies on several approaches (Herna ́ ndez-Alvarez and Gomez, 2016) to develop a classifier based on (1) structural characteristics that describe where the quote is located, (2) lexical and grammatical characteristics for the way the quote is described, (3) field characteristics that take into account the location or other external information, and (4) usage characteristics as the reference is quoted throughout the essay. Table 3 shows our characteristics, including those derived from state-of-the-art systems (Teufel, 2000; Teufel et al., 2006b; Dong and Schasfer, 2011; Wan and Liu, 2014; Valenzuela et al., 2015), as well as ten novel feature classes.

sections.heading: 4 Narrative Structure of Citation Function
sections.text: In the next four sections, we apply the classifier trained on our combined dataset (3083 cases of citation function, 1969 cases of centrality of citation) 4In fact, replacing the classifier used in Devil (2000) with a random forest improves the classification of the citation function by 0.123 (Macro F1) and 0.175 (Micro F1).In the ACL Anthology, we examine which citation roles can tell us about scientific acceptance and direction.As a qualitative demonstration, we first examine the narrative structure of the citation function across the section. Scientific work usually follows a structured narration according to section: Introduction, Methodology, Results and Discussion (Skelton, 1994; Nwogu, 1997).Each part of the narration adopts argumentative steps designed to convince the reader of the claims of the work (Swales, 1986; Swales, 1990).We expect this narration to be reflected in the use of its quotations in sections, with this section reflecting the 1974, the framework for the hypothesis that section 1274 has been applied.

sections.heading: 5 Venues and Citation Patterns
sections.text: We used the same experimental setup as in the previous section. Figure 3 shows citation function by location for the 134,127 citations. We note that similar locations have similar citation functions. Journals have the highest proportion of BACKGROUND citations, suggesting that their extra space and timing are better suited for positioning. Conference venues devote proportionately more space to contrast and comparison, presumably because new NLP work is presented at conferences for the first time and therefore a demonstration of the proposed technique is better than existing ones. Workshops, on the other hand, have relatively few comparisons and use more BACKGROUND; the experimental nature of workshop work probably leads to fewer potential comparative perspectives.

sections.heading: 6 Citation Network Navigation
sections.text: s understanding of their behavior is an important part of the understanding of scientists collecting their goals and strategies. However, while human navigation has been extensively researched in hyper-networked networks such as Wikipedia (e.g. West and Leskovec (2012), we know very little about how scientists trawl through their citation networks (Rouse et al., 1982) and Whitehead Jr., and no studies have looked at real-world data tracking user behavior. Have readers generally followed links to methodologies to follow essential papers? ACL Anthology provides an opportunity to examine these questions in detail, as the anthology server logs allow us to estimate when readers follow quotes from one paper to another.

sections.heading: 7 Predicting Future Impact
sections.text: The scientific narrative narrated by quotations provides the reader with support for his claims and technical competence (Latour, 1987, p. 34). This framework could influence the perception of the work and, ultimately, how it is received and quoted within the community (Shi et al., 2010). Is the narrative a paper constructed by quotation roles (the way it compares with related works, or motivates, or refers to the ultimate quotation number) to its reception? Experimental Setup To quantify the effects of quotation use, we test its ability to predict the cumulative number of citations received within the first five years of publication by a paper known to be highly representative of the final quotation number (Wang et al., 2013). Our base model consists of state-of-art features for predicting the quotation numbers (Yan et al., 2011; Yan et al., 2012; Chakraet al, 2014; Dong et, 2016; and Dong, 2014; and Dong, Dong, 2014).

sections.heading: 8 The Growth of Rapid Discovery Science
sections.text: As scientific fields evolve, new subfields are often based first on methodological technology, triggering a community discussion about the best way to use and improve technology (Moody, 2004).NLP has observed the emergence of several such subfields from the early grammatical approaches in the 1950s-1970s to the statistical revolution in the 1990s to the most recent methodological models (SPA, Jones, 2001; Anderson et al., 2012).Collins (1994) has suggested that one field can undergo a certain shift in what he calls rapid discovery science (a) achieves high consensus on research topics and methods, and (b) develops genealogies of methodological technologies that build on another. As a result of increased consensus, one field emphasizes the movement toward new research problems rather than reviewing the results of earlier approaches. Collins claims that this shift characterizes natural sciences, but not many social sciences that tend to emphasize this process.

sections.heading: 9 Conclusion
sections.text: Using a new corpus with citation function and centrality, we develop a state-of-the-art classifier that identifies the importance of new uncontrolled features in relation to theme models and argumentation structures and identifies all quotations for an entire field (with all data and materials published at https: / / github. com / anon). Subsequently, we show that citation function and centrality reveal outstanding behaviors of writers, readers, and the field as a whole: (1) Authors are sensitive to discourse structure and place of quotation, (2) readers follow temporal thread ideas and not methodological threads when surfing citation networks, (3) the way in which an author relates their work to literature is predictable for the number of citations they receive, with the community preferring well-motivated works that integrate and compare with other works, and (4) the NLP field as a whole has an increased consensus - which is a quick reference to the science and a need for validated work.

Because they tend to be unidimensional, they can’t label both centrality and function (Swales, 1986), they often include fine-grained distinctions too rare to reliably identify and subjective classifications that require detailed field or author knowledge (Ziman, 1968; Swales, 1990; Harwood, 2009).

Because they tend to be unidimensional, they can’t label both centrality and function (Swales, 1986), they often include fine-grained distinctions too rare to reliably identify and subjective classifications that require detailed field or author knowledge (Ziman, 1968; Swales, 1990; Harwood, 2009).

Because they tend to be unidimensional, they can’t label both centrality and function (Swales, 1986), they often include fine-grained distinctions too rare to reliably identify and subjective classifications that require detailed field or author knowledge (Ziman, 1968; Swales, 1990; Harwood, 2009).

Our classification builds on two themes for citation role: (1) citation centrality, which reflects whether the citation is used to position the contribution within a broader context or is essential for understanding the contribution itself (Moravcsik and Murugesan, 1975; Chubin and Moitra, 1975; Swales, 1986; Latour, 1987; Valenzuela et al., 2015) and (2) citation function, which reflects the particular purpose a citation is serving in the discourse, e.

A third potential theme is citation sentiment (Athar, 2014; Kumar, 2016), but we omit this because researchers have shown that negative sentiment is rare in practice (Chubin and Moitra, 1975; Vinkler, 1998; Case and Higgins, 2000) and quite subjecCentrality In citing, an author attempts to persuade the reader of a paper’s merit (Gilbert, 1977) by incorporating other work to further their own approach, or by contextualizing their work within the broader literature.

Both kinds of citations are necessary; for example as Latour (1987) and others have argued, positioning citations secure the inductive gaps between an author’s arguments, and allow the author to identify with a lineage of work as motivation for their own position.

Annotation guidelines were created using a pilot study of 10 papers sampled from the ACL Anthology Reference Corpus (ARC) (Bird et al., 2008).
All citations were then doubly-annotated by two trained annotators using the Brat tool (Stenetorp et al., 2012) and then fully adjudicated to ensure quality.
Each paper was processed using ParsCit (Councill et al., 2008) to extract citations and their references.

Our work draws on multiple approaches (Hernández-Alvarez and Gomez, 2016) to develop a classifier based on (1) structural features describing where the citation is located, (2) lexical and grammatical features for how the citation is described, (3) field features that take into account venue or other external information, and (4) usage features on how the reference is cited throughout the paper.

Table 3 shows our features, including those drawn from state of the art systems (Teufel, 2000; Teufel et al., 2006b; Dong and Schäfer, 2011; Wan and Liu, 2014; Valenzuela et al., 2015) as well as ten novel feature classes.

Pattern-based Features Patterns provide a powerful mechanisms for capturing regularity in citation usage (Dong and Schäfer, 2011).
” We began with the largest publicly-available list of citation patterns (Teufel, 2000), extending it with 132 new patterns and 13 new lexical categories based on a manual analysis of the corpus.
To avoid semantic drift (Riloff and Jones, 1999), a bootstrapped pattern was only included as a feature if the majority of its occurrences were with a single citation function.
Previous patterns primarily use cues from the same sentence as the citation (Teufel, 2000).

Models All models were trained using a Random Forest classifier, which is robust to overfitting even with large numbers of features (Fernández-Delgado et al., 2014). After limited grid search, we set the number of random trees to 500, initialized trees using a balanced subsample of the data, and required each leaf to match 7 instances. The classifier is implemented using SciKit (Pedregosa et al., 2011) and syntactic processing was done using CoreNLP (Manning et al., 2014). Selectional preferences used pretrained 300-dimensional vectors from the 840B token Common Crawl (Pennington et al., 2014). Data Annotated data is crucial for developing high accuracy for rare citation classes. Therefore, we integrate portions of the dataset of Teufel (2010), which has fine-grained citation function labeled for ACL-related documents using the annotation scheme of Teufel et al.

Models All models were trained using a Random Forest classifier, which is robust to overfitting even with large numbers of features (Fernández-Delgado et al., 2014). After limited grid search, we set the number of random trees to 500, initialized trees using a balanced subsample of the data, and required each leaf to match 7 instances. The classifier is implemented using SciKit (Pedregosa et al., 2011) and syntactic processing was done using CoreNLP (Manning et al., 2014). Selectional preferences used pretrained 300-dimensional vectors from the 840B token Common Crawl (Pennington et al., 2014). Data Annotated data is crucial for developing high accuracy for rare citation classes. Therefore, we integrate portions of the dataset of Teufel (2010), which has fine-grained citation function labeled for ACL-related documents using the annotation scheme of Teufel et al. (2006b). We map their 12 function classes into six of ours.

Scientific papers commonly follow a structured narrative according to section: Introduction, Methodology, Results, and Discussion (Skelton, 1994; Nwogu, 1997).
Scientific papers commonly follow a structured narrative according to section: Introduction, Methodology, Results, and Discussion (Skelton, 1994; Nwogu, 1997).
Each part in the narrative adopts argumentative moves designed to convince the reader of the work’s claims (Swales, 1986; Swales, 1990).
Each part in the narrative adopts argumentative moves designed to convince the reader of the work’s claims (Swales, 1986; Swales, 1990).
We expect that this narrative is mirrored in how authors use their citations in sections, with the section serving to frame the meaning of a citation (Goffman, 1974; Gumperz, 1982).
We expect that this narrative is mirrored in how authors use their citations in sections, with the section serving to frame the meaning of a citation (Goffman, 1974; Gumperz, 1982).
These trends also mirror the thematic structure identified in full-paper textual analyses (Skelton, 1994; Nwogu, 1997).

By showing that a section contains citations serving a variety of functions, our findings further point to a new direction for citation placement studies (Hu et al., 2013; Ding et al., 2013; Bertin et al., 2016), which have largely treated all citations within a section as equivalent.

Our baseline model consists of state of the art features for predicting citation count (Yan et al., 2011; Yan et al., 2012; Chakraborty et al., 2014; Dong et al., 2016); we then ask whether prediction is improved by adding the number of citations per function and centrality.

Multi-author papers are known to receive higher citation counts (Gazni and Didegah, 2011), partially due to the effects of selfcitation (Fowler and Aksnes, 2007), and therefore we include the number of authors on the paper.

To control for collinearity between citation-related predictors, we regress out the number of citations from the citation function counts and then in turn, regress out the citation function counts from citation centrality counts (Kutner et al., 2004; Obrien, 2007).

To control for collinearity between citation-related predictors, we regress out the number of citations from the citation function counts and then in turn, regress out the citation function counts from citation centrality counts (Kutner et al., 2004; Obrien, 2007).
As scientific fields evolve, new subfields are often initially based around method technology, which starts a community discussion of the best way to use and improve the technology (Moody, 2004).

NLP has witnessed the emergence of several such subfields from the early grammar based approaches in the 1950s-1970s to the statistical revolution in the 1990s to the recent deep learning models (Spärck Jones, 2001; Anderson et al., 2012).

NLP has witnessed the emergence of several such subfields from the early grammar based approaches in the 1950s-1970s to the statistical revolution in the 1990s to the recent deep learning models (Spärck Jones, 2001; Anderson et al., 2012). Collins (1994) proposed that a field can undergo a particular shift, to what he calls rapid discovery science, when the field (a) reaches high consensus on research top-

We propose that the increased use of shared evaluations, and the statistical methodology borrowed originally from electrical engineering (Hall et al., 2008) has led NLP to undergo a shift towards rapid discovery science.

These trends show the increased incorporation of prior work to form a lineage of method technologies as well as show increased consensus on which works are sufficient for comparing against in order to establish a claim. These results also empirically confirm the observation of Spärck Jones (2001) that a major trend in NLP in
the 1990s was an increase in reusable technologies and evaluations, like the BNC (Leech, 1992) and the Penn Treebank (Marcus et al.
the 1990s was an increase in reusable technologies and evaluations, like the BNC (Leech, 1992) and the Penn Treebank (Marcus et al., 1993).

metadata.abstractText: Citations are an important indicator of the state of a scientific field, reflecting how authors frame their work, and influencing uptake by future scholars. However, our understanding of citation behavior has been limited to small-scale manual citation analysis. We perform the largest behavioral study of citations to date, analyzing how citations are both framed and taken up by scholars in one entire field: natural language processing. We introduce a new dataset of nearly 2,000 citations annotated for function and centrality, and use it to develop a state-of-the-art classifier and label the entire ACL Reference Corpus. We then study how citations are framed by authors and use both papers and online traces to track how citations are followed by readers. We demonstrate that authors are sensitive to discourse structure and publication venue when citing, that online readers follow temporal links to previous and future work rather than methodological links, and that how a paper cites related work is predictive of its citation count. Finally, we use changes in citation roles to show that the field of NLP is undergoing a significant increase in consensus.
metadata.creator: LaTeX with hyperref package
